answers.answer: Stress does not cause neuropathy, but during an illness such as pneumonia (or any porlonged illness) there are various stressors on the body such as decreased nutrition, decreased activity, etc which can contribute to the development of a neuropathy. Neuropathy just means peripheral nerve damage - which can be very mild and reversible (usually when only the lining of the  nerve is damaged) to severe (when a part of the nerve may die and not recover). Recovery can take up to one year, although startes within weeks of reversal of the stressors. Sometimes this is called 'critical illness polyneuropathy'. There may be some residual symptoms - the sensory nerves in the feet are among the most susceptible to damage as they are the longest distance from their source of nutrition/origin close to the spinal cord. Hence there may be some intermittent or fluctuating sensory symptoms in these areas. It does not rule out another cause like a pinched nerve, but it si a possibility.Good luck

i just wanted to add onemore thing besides the headaches, this is really wierd but during and after having sex both the arches of my feet cramp so bad its like they just lock up and is very painfull. im sure is has to do with whatever is wrong with my legs and feet. thanks again,george

Have you been checked for diabetes?  A glucose tolerance test over a couple of hours rather than just a fasting glc would be best.  Diabetic neuropathy starts in the hands and feet and illness can bring on diabetes.

I had a check by blood for diabetes back in november twice.  Both times is was negative.  I have been not been checked recently.  I am going to my regular doctor to check on any other factors that might be causing my feet to burn and tingle along with the numbness.  I have been back exercising again and I have been standing on my feet for hours at a time due to a second job I have.  I am wondering if I have a oxygen/nutrient deficiency that is causing this.  Has anyone heard of such a thing?

Have you checked what medications you took during your pneumonia?. Your symptoms might be a consequence of an inmune reaction to the infection, or a delayed reaction to the drugs prescribed for your illness. Some antibiotics cause very long term symptoms (years) similar to the ones that you describe.

hello, my name is george and im a 50 year old male.after searching for sometime and reading your post all i can say is WOW.i to have had pneumonia twice, years ago. and have been suffering with the numbness and tingling in both legs and feet. at times my toes feel like there on fire and now my hands are getting this way, tingling that is.its worse at night and the only way it goes away if i sleep for a few hours.some things bring it on right away, like paint fumes. a friend paints cars and a few months ago i went into the spray booth to look at one of the cars  and before i could get out of there my lower body started buzzing.im into hobby model boats and just one whiff of paint thiner causes my legs to buzz as does driving, sitting at my computer or just sitting in a chair. some nights it gets so bad i feel like its going to be my death.the doc at the clinic cant seem to help me and i cant seem to find any help anywheres? so i do hope that someone here can give answers.it just dawned on me that it could be from my lungs and it feels like my feet are dieing. but anyway i feel for you and do hope we both can find answers, good luck to you,,george

Hi Guys, This may or may not seem rediculous to you, but I have a suggestion for you both. I have had similar problems to you with the buzzing and burning plus a whole lot of other symptoms I won't go into. As yet I am undiagnosed as my MRI was clear. But my Neurologist had one possible diagnosis and that was Hyperventilation. Apparently when the brain gets too much oxygen, it can cause all sorts of weird symptoms - estecially buzzing extremities and neuropathys. One cause of this can be stress, but in both your cases, I wonder if the pnuemonia could have kicked it off - given it would have been hard to breath and maybe you over compensated and began to breathe too much. Its just a thought - I'm no doctor, but I started to wonder where things like post sex and exercise exasperations where happening for you. Its been ruled out for me, if anything, I don't breathe enough. It'll be interesting to see what the neuro says.Good luck.

Have any of you had your B-12 level checked? Peripheral neuropathy is one of the symptoms of low B-12. Numbness is what sent me to a neurologist, where they found low B-12. It can be dangerous if left untreated.      Good Luck

when i was a teenager in high school, the guys rolleed me up in a mat and they all dove on it. i was bent over and something gave away in my back and ever sence then ive had back problems.i cant help to think after all these years that there is more wrong then just a back ache. im sure no doctor and cant afford one. do any doctors come to this site??? or is it just a guessing game???
it sounds like a reaction from the medication you took for pneumonia.

I am a 65 year old female in relatively good health.  However, I am also dealing with numbness in my feet.  It started with the big toe and has progressed up my foot.  It is typical of neuropathy symptom of feeling that you have a sock or slipper on and you don't.  Was tested for neuropathy (a shocking experience) and it proved negative.  Neurologist ordered a blood test and found I was B-12 deficient.  I have been taking shots for three months but have had no improvement,  In fact, it seems to have progressed further up my foot and a burning sensation has been added in one foot.  I am also not diabetic.  While it is just annoying right now, I am concerned about the progression of my problem.  I do have arthritis and wonder if it could be affecting my nerves due to pressure.  However, I can't see it affecting both feet if this were the case.  I see my neurologist again next month.  Any suggestions of possible causes that I might bring to the appointment?

hi there jean im having a similar problem with my left foot at the moment and i loked up alot of stuff on the internet today look up gout and see what you thinkit does say that gout usually starts in the big toe and then progressesim no doctor hun but you may find this use full it also says that gout has something to do with arthritis as wellgood luck mf and hope you find out what it is and how to cure it

question: I had an episode of neuropathy from being sick with pneumonia for about a month back in november and december.  My neurologist said my neuropathy was caused from stress and being so worn down from the illness.  I had a eng done and a brain mri to rule out any other illnesses.  I have no real weakness but it has taken me some time to recover and get back to full strength.  I had serious twitching and extremity pain until about January.  I have been feeling better and started exercising for the past 3 weeks which includes vigorous running,  but over the past 2-3 weeks I now have had some buzzing, numbness, in my left foot and pain in both feet.  My toes burn every once in a while.  Most of the numbness is while I sit or lay down, and the burning is when I walk.  I am experiencing some lower back pain.  I am wondering if this is my neuropathy coming back or maybe a pinched nerve or disk problem.  Also, does stress trigger neuropathy?   Any help would be appreciated
title: numbness, buzzing in feet
